The prime minister raised the subject during talks with US President Barack Obama at the White House. Critics of existing rules say they make the extradition of UK nationals an unacceptable precedent.


Under Section 51 of the Lisbon treaty, foreign nationals being arrested or detained abroad within Europe must show "reasonable legal certainty" that they will avoid being extradited. The process of being tried in their native country is usually lengthy, but it is often accompanied by a court hearing or trial. Foreign nationals can seek to have the court sentence them to 15,000 hours of community service.

"Our international relations are more complex than we may realize," said Cameron. "We are not in a permanent diplomatic alliance without strong laws and agreements."
